abstract: In recent times, machine learning has advanced substantially from a scientific novelty to a practical technology in pervasive commercial use. Moreover, machine learning has emerged as the preferred method for introducing practical applications for image and signal processing, speech synthesis, computer vision, natural language processing, object tracking, and other applications (Chen, Deng and Wang). Additionally, it is now widely recognized by many artificial intelligence (AI) developers that, for many applications, it is far more efficient to train a system by depicting it with examples of desired input/output (I/O) behavior rather than conventionally programming it by predicting the expected response for all possible inputs (Welling). Furthermore, machine learning has also had a significant impact on computer science and a variety of businesses involved with several data-intensive issues, including user services, fault diagnostics in complex processing systems, logistics, and supply chain control (Choudhury, Counts and Horvitz).
